summary: FIPV is an enveloped virus with a nonsegmented, positive sense, single-stranded RNA genome. it is grouped as feline coronavirus (FCoV), under the family Coronaviridae. the relationship between these two biotypes remains unclear. antiviral drugs such as ribavirin, interferons, and immunosuppressive drugs have been used as treatments for infected cats. however, those treatments were ineffective. there is still significant unmet medical need to develop effective treatments and prophylactics for FIPV infection. the results were recorded after 72 hours. the virus tissue culture infective dose 50 (TCID50) was calculated using Reed and Muench's method. '3′UTR and 29335–29344 TFO3 GGAUAAGAGGAA C C C GGACAAGAGGAA 5′ caggattctctctctctaccga 3′ ORF1a/1b and 530–541 TFO4 AAAGAGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG each TFO RNA was mixed with the target region in 1X binding buffer containing 25 mM Tris-HCl, 6 mM MgCl2 and 10 mMNaCl. the sample was run on 15% native polyacrylamide gel at 80 V, in cool condition. viral inoculum was replaced by fresh maintenance media (MEM containing 1% FBS and 1% pen/strep) morphology of the cultures was recorded 72 hours after infection. samples were harvested at this time point and stored at 80°C. reverse transcriptase quantitative real-time PCR was performed using a bio-Rad CFX96 real-time system. reaction was amplified in a final volume of 25 L using a SensiMix SYBR No-Rox One-Step reaction buffer, 10 units RiboSafe RNase inhibitor, and 5 L template RNA. data were represented as mean SE of three independent tests. one-way ANOVA, Tukey post hoc test was used to analyze the significant level among the data. a serial 10-fold dilution of FIPV was prepared from the working stock. the linear TFOs were modified with phosphate (PO4) group and hydroxide (OH) group. these modifications were necessary for the circularization of linear TFO. the process of circularization was carried out according to the manufacturer's protocol. denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis was performed as described before [19] with modification. 20% of denatured urea polyacrylamide gel was prepared and polymerized for 30 minutes. five L of TFO RNA mixed with 5 L of urea loading buffer was heated at 92°C for 2 minutes. the experiment was run at 37°C with 2 L/injection, for a total of 25 injections. data was collected every 250 seconds and analyzed using the software v2.3.6 provided by the manufacturer. 100TCID50 of influenza A virus subtype H1N1 New Jersey 8/76 (ATCC VR-897) was inoculated into the plate for 1 hour at 37°C. the viral RNA was extracted from 100 L of the harvested cell culture using a QIAamp viral RNA extraction kit (Qiagen, Germany) YBR No-ROX One-Step Kit (Bioline, UK) consisted of 12.5 L 2X SensiMix SYBR No-Rox One-Step reaction buffer, 10 M forward and reverse primers, 10 units RiboSafe RNase inhibitor, and 5 L template RNA. a standard curve of a serial dilution of virus was plotted before the quantification. the target regions were 5′ untranslated region (5′ UTR), Open Reading Frames (ORFs) 1a and 1b, and 3′ untranslated region (3′ UTR) both ends of the duplex TFOs were ligated with a linker sequence or clamps (C-C) to construct circular TFO RNA. EMSA analysis illustrated binding of circular TFO1, 3, 4, and 5 to the target regions as evidenced by upward band shift. binding of each circular TFO except circular TFO2 to its respective target forms a complex that migrate slower than unbound TFO. the stronger the binding is, the more stable the triplex structure forms. the data analyzed by one-way ANOVA, Tukey post hoc test showed significant high viral RNA genome copy number of 4.03 1014 for virus inoculated cells. the viral RNA copies of circular TFO1, TFO3, TFO4, and unrelated circular TFO7 RNAs transfected cells also showed high viral RNA copy numbers which did not show significant differences to the infected cells. the experimental conditions were identical to that of the previous experiment except for TFO1 concentrations of 25 nM, 50 nM, 100 nM, and 500 nM. no significant reduction in viral RNA genome copies using the concentration of 25 nM TFO1. the target regions were 5′ untranslated region (5′ UTR), Open Reading Frames (ORFs) 1a and 1b, and 3′ untranslated region (3′ UTR) both ends of the duplex TFOs were ligated with a linker sequence or clamps (C-C) to construct circular TFO RNA. EMSA analysis illustrated the binding of circular TFO1, 3, 4, and 5 to its respective target regions as evidenced by upward band shift. binding of each circular TFO except circular TFO2 to its respective target forms a complex that migrate slower than unbound TFO. the results showed viral RNA genome copy numbers of 3.65 109, 3.22 1014, 5.04 109, 5.01 109, 4.41 109, and 3.96 1014 in cells treated with TFO1, TFO2, TFO3, TFO4, and TFO5 treatments. the viral RNA copies of circular TFO1, TFO3, TFO4, and unrelated circular TFO7 RNAs transfected cells also showed high viral RNA copy numbers. the experimental conditions were identical to that of the previous experiment, except for TFO1 concentrations of 25 nM, 50 nM, 100 nM, and 500 nM. the other concentrations caused significant reductions in copy numbers compared to the virus-infected cells. development of antiviral therapies against FIPV using siRNA [25] and viral protease inhibitors [26] has been tested as potential new treatments against FIPV infection. ligated circular TFOs were evaluated using PAGE analysis. no antiviral properties were detected from the linear TFOs and unrelated circular TFO7 RNA. however, no antiviral properties were detected from the linear TFOs. binding of the circular TFO to the target region was confirmed by nanoITC analysis. the circular TFOs were designed in such way that the presence of hydrogen bonding donors and acceptors in the purines is able to form two hydrogen bonds. the pyrimidine bases can only form one additional hydrogen bond with incoming third bases. however, there are various factors that may limit the activity of TFOs in cells like intracellular degradation of the TFO and limited accessibility of the TFO to the target sites. the inability of TFO2 to show antiviral effect due to failure in the formation of functional tertiary structure of the triplex formation cannot be ruled out. in vitro antiviral study which showed no antiviral property for unrelated TFO (TFO7) and also inability of circular TFO1 and TFO5 to inhibit influenza A virus H1N1 infected cells confirm the specificity of the TFOs' activity. 1N1 replication showed no significant reduction in viral RNA genome copy numbers between the TFO RNA transfected cells and untransfected cells (p 0.05). data are average of 3 independent tests (mean SE) Conflict of interests The authors have declared that no conflict of interests exists.
